questions.question_text: Which of the following choices may be global variables for steps in horizontal discovery patterns? (Choose two.)

choices.D: A Windows Server CI is created, then updated with WindowsSN1 as the name.
choices.A: A Windows Server CI is created, then updated with WindowsSN2 as the name.
choices.C: Two Windows Server CIs are created, without serial_number values.
choices.B: Two Windows Sewer CIs are created, with WindowsSN1 AND WindowsSN2 for names.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I say A as well.
the question says "subsequent discovery is run against a different windows server" this implies that there is a second windows server to consider. In this case, the answer has to be B.
A = serial number match as unique

Selected Answer: A
I believe A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

the OOB IRE rule has a higher priority for the serial number (derived from the Hardware Class), IRE will stop with the first matching condition that delivery a unique identification, therefore it would consider the serialnumber as significant. Thus I opt for A
I would say the answer is A, it would only NOT update the name if a less authoritative data source was used.
looks to be A as unique serial

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A.

Selected Answer: B
B i guess
A as the serial number unique.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
Probably A.
NOT sure why 2 new data needs to be created

questions.question_text:
A discovery runs against a Windows Server returning the following attribute values for the first time: name = WindowsSN1 serial_number = 12321
A subsequent discovery runs against a different Windows Server returning the following attribute values: name = WindowsSN2 serial_number = 12321
With only base system CI Identifiers configured, which of the following is true?
